results.title: Every child a winner!
results.creator_credit: Charles F. Holbrook and American Alliance for Health, Physical Education, and Recreation
results.brief_description: Presents a case history of a program which demonstrates the values of individualised movement-based physical education, the Project Health and Optimum Physical Education program. Demonstrates the results of the program which concentrates on children at the elementary grade level. For teacher training.

results.title: Event horse
results.creator_credit: Robin Crane and Robin Crane Films
results.brief_description: Based on Sheila Willcox’s book “The Event horse”. Tells the story of the training of a “green” horse up to the winning of a novice horse trial. Training technicalities are presented in an interesting way, and the whole story of training and competing is designed to give people a better understanding of the purpose and requirements of a horse trial.

results.title: The Importance of listening
results.creator_credit: Richard Murison, Barbara Dunning, Meredith D. Gall, Educational Research and Development and Teacher Education and Far West Laboratory
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Discussing Controversial Issues”.
If a discussion is to be useful it is essential to listen. The onus to keep the discussion going is on both the moderator and the participants. The moderator should: Summarise ideas and restore issues. The participants should: Listen to the other person’s ideas, acknowledge others’ ideas, question relevance. The case represented in this film is a discussion between black and white high school students and a white policeman concerning a fatal police shooting of a black man. The film uses this topic to illustrate skills of keeping a discussion on track (as a mediator) and relating participants’ comments and questions to each other.

results.title: Understanding different points of view
results.creator_credit: Richard Murison, Barbara Dunning, Meredith D. Gall and Far West Laboratory for Educational Research and Development
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Discussing Controversial Issues”
Explains that to provide good discussion and to understand other points of view the participants should: give reasons, ask for reasons and ask for clarification; while the Moderator should: ask for reasons, state areas of agreement and disagreement and ask for temporary agreement.

results.title: Evaluating your discussion
results.creator_credit: Educational Research and Development and Teachers Education Program and Far West Laboratory
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Discussing Controversial Issues”.
Designed to help high school students with evaluating and discussing controversial issues. The topics in this film are: George Orwell’s “1984”; Students Appeal Board; and Police reactions - role reversal.

results.title: Creating an open discussion
results.creator_credit: Richard Murison, Barbara Dunning, Meredith D. Gall and Far West Laboratory for Educational Research and Development
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discussing Controversial Issues”.
By providing topics for discussion teachers acting as moderators in separate classrooms show how a discussion can be productively carried out. The film clearly shows the jobs of both the moderator and the participants. Shows how to develop an open (non-threatening) situation in which meaningful discussions can take place.

results.title: Eureka
results.brief_description: Highly commended entry into the “Make a stamp come alive” category of Screen It! This film recounts the story of famous revolt in Ballarat and the subsequent discovery of gold. An animated short entered to ACMI’s ‘Screen It’ media making competition for Primary Schools.

results.title: Eucalyptus oil distillery [excerpt]
results.brief_description: At the end of the war in 1946, Horrie Vernon and his brother set up a eucalyptus oil distillery in the small town of St Arnaud in Victoria. In this excerpt (which is part of a longer sequence) Horrie, who is still working the distillery, talks about how the eucalyptus oil is produced: from the collecting of the leaves, to the boiling of the leaves, the collecting of the steam and allowing it to condense, and finally, to the skimming of the oil off the surface. This process which is still carried out in the same way today. is demonstrated in the film.
